citations.narrative:
The facility's disposition records are incomplete. The written inventory for parakeets is listed at 198. There are 185 birds
present in the facility during inspection. The facility has not been recording when birds are transported, sold, euthanized,
or otherwise disposed of by the exhibitor.
Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper identification, to trace and track animals in case of
disease outbreak, and to ensure all parties that are required to be licensed have a current, valid license.
Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following
information concerning animals, other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or
otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise
disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring of any animal while in his or her possession
or under his or her control.
Correct by September 11, 2024

The door to the exhibit holding four ring-tail lemurs has not been replaced when worn. The majority of the door’s wooden
bottom rail is scratched, exposing untreated wood. Failure to maintain surfaces of housing facilities hinders the ability to
adequately clean and sanitize and may affect the health and well-being of the animals. All surfaces must be maintained
on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized must be replaced when
worn or soiled.
Correct by September 11, 2024

Trash cans in the housing facilities are not leakproof and do not have tightly fitted lids. Approximately eight trash cans
containing refuse from the lemur and squirrel monkey exhibits, among other species, are present at the rear of the
housing room. The trash cans lids have a circular hole cut in the top of the lid to allow for storage when not in use. Thus,
the trash cans are not leakproof and do not minimize vermin and pest hazards. The facility must ensure that trash
containers in housing facilities and in food storage and food preparation areas are leakproof and have tightly fitted lids on
them at all times.
Correct by September 11, 2024
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class C license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 1, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility's disposition records are incomplete. The written inventory for parakeets is listed at 198. There are 185 birds 
present in the facility during inspection. The facility has not been recording when birds are transported, sold, euthanized, 
or otherwise disposed of by the exhibitor.  
 
Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper identification, to trace and track animals in case of 
disease outbreak, and to ensure all parties that are required to be licensed have a current, valid license. 
 
Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following 
information concerning animals, other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or 
otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise 
disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring of any animal while in his or her possession 
or under his or her control. 
 
Correct by September 11, 2024 
3.75(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The door to the exhibit holding four ring-tail lemurs has not been replaced when worn. The majority of the door’s wooden 
bottom rail is scratched, exposing untreated wood. Failure to maintain surfaces of housing facilities hinders the ability to 
adequately clean and sanitize and may affect the health and well-being of the animals. All surfaces must be maintained 
on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized must be replaced when 
worn or soiled. 
 
Correct by September 11, 2024 
3.75(f) 
   
Housing facilities, general.

Trash cans in the housing facilities are not leakproof and do not have tightly fitted lids. Approximately eight trash cans 
containing refuse from the lemur and squirrel monkey exhibits, among other species, are present at the rear of the 
housing room. The trash cans lids have a circular hole cut in the top of the lid to allow for storage when not in use. Thus, 
the trash cans are not leakproof and do not minimize vermin and pest hazards. The facility must ensure that trash 
containers in housing facilities and in food storage and food preparation areas are leakproof and have tightly fitted lids on 
them at all times. 
 
Correct by September 11, 2024 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class C license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 1, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
